content:
(Cf. †T510.) *Encyc.
Rel. Ethics Index 272a; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
child:
Proclamation of dogma of Immaculate Conception stops
plague.

Man miraculously dies for opposing dogma of Immaculate
Conception.

Attempt to disprove the dogma
by false miracle. Sham dead man is to rise if the dogma is not true. He is
found to be actually dead. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 554.

content: Belief in the life to come.
child: Doctrine of immortality taught by druids.
Man converted to belief in future life on deathbed.

Feels sure nevertheless that nothing will come of it.
Wesselski Bebel I 182 No. 32.
Dying man refuses to believe in life to come.

Given choice between life and heaven, person chooses
latter.

Hermit wants to prove truth of these words of the Gospel
and asks for the hand of the princess. Performs the difficult task imposed upon
him. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 779*; Russian: Andrejev No. 841I*.

content: Heathen baptized into devil‘s possession. Irish myth: *Cross.

Temple about to be taken over by pagans saved by appearance
of a Sign of the Cross (image of the Virgin).
Dove flies out of man‘s mouth.

Impious anchorite has agreed to forsake his religion in
return for the possession of a maid. When he repents the dove reenters his
mouth. Italian Novella: Rotunda; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Idols found on their faces after saint’s arrival.

Author of book against heretic honored by Virgin Mary and
angels.

Jews protesting against marriage of Jewess and Christian
are struck dumb.

Hero renounces heaven because dead companions (heathen) are
not there.

Man sets fire to his house and perishes in it rather than
accept Christianity.

German: H. Rauchfuss Alte Geschichte u. neue Sagen aus
Thuringen 60.

Jewish child thrown into oven by father for taking
eucharist.

Preserved by Virgin Mary. *Ward II 601; Irish myth: Cross (†V35.1.0.1); Spanish
Exempla: Keller.
child:
Jewish child resurrected (saved by power of Virgin Mary)
after being burned to ashes for eating consecrated bread in Christian church.

content: Pagan sybil draws picture of Madonna and Child in sand.
Result of vision. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 560.

(Cf. †M177.1.) Pauli
(ed. Bolte) No. 555; Dickson 199 n. 89; Malone PMLA XLIII 413. -- Irish:
*Cross, O’Suilleabhain 65, Beal XXI 325;
Icelandic: *Boberg; English: Wells 88 (Roland and Vernagu); Spanish Exempla:
Keller; Jewish: *Neuman; Tahiti: Henry Ancient Tahiti (Honolulu, 1928) 178.
child:
Three (two) Irishmen who believed in Christianity before
the coming of St. Patrick.

Dickson 193--98 passim; Alphabet No. 558; Icelandic:
*Boberg; Irish: *Cross, O‘Suilleabhain 71, 74, Beal XXI 326; English: Wells 91
(Otuel), 119 (Octovian), *Hibbard 45ff.; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Conversion to Christianity by miracle of seeing blood flow
from Jesus’ image.

Conversion to Christianity through appearance of the cross
and angels.

Conversion to Christianity because the heathen gods prove
to be less powerful.

Conversion because saint‘s staff miraculously goes through
neophytes’ foot.
Conversion to Christianity on pain of death.
Miraculous beautification upon conversion to Christianity.
Conversion to Christianity out of gratitude.

Ruler has captive baptize his sister and then marry her.
Grateful for past kindnesses. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Saladin asks to be made a Christian knight.

Swans (transformed children) do not suffer in harsh weather
after conversion to Christianity.

Conversion to Christianity because of admiration for
Christian virtue.

Conversion to Christianity through show of forgiveness and
gentleness.

content: Baptismal water vanishes before Aryan bishop.
Heathen beats his god because of misfortune.
Doctor ridicules belief in Devil, Heaven, and Hell.

child: Prolonged prostration in worship causes death.

Hindu drinks water by mistake from Mohammedan‘s vessel: his
fortune turns to evil.

content:
Romans won’t include Jesus in their pantheon because of his
poverty which they hate.

Insane man burns heretic in his bed: restored to his senses
as reward.
A Christianized Jew becomes a priest.

During Mass, he stabs
the consecrated host, blood flows (cf. †C55, †J1261.2, †V30). He kills the
other priest who saw him commit the sacrilege, and before killing, forces him
to renounce his faith. A miracle exposes the murderer. Lithuanian: Balys Index
No. 3270, Legends Nos. 416ff.

child: Saint dispels pagan devils from ancient shrines.

Pagan shrines and idols, or magic books destroyed by fire
from heaven.

Heathen idols sink into earth up to their necks through
power of saint.
Saint’s bachall pointed at idol defaces it.

content:
Buddhists become slaves of Taoists because they cannot
produce rain.
Life of heroic age preferable to Christian living.
Pagan disputant with Christian stricken dumb.

English: Wells 76 (Joseph of Aramathie); Spanish Exempla:
Keller.
child:
Pagan disputant with Christian bested by the words put in
his mouth by God.

content: Duel (debate) to prove which religion is better.

Dickson 187 nn. 61, 62; English: Wells 88 (Roland and
Vernagu), 91 (Otuel); Spanish Exempla: Keller.
child: Wise heretic is vanquished in debate with a Christian.
Brahmin wins a discussion on religion.
Magician overpowered in contest with a saint.
Contest of St. Peter with Simon Magus, a magician.
Prayer-contest to prove which religion is better.

Contest of miraculous powers between a Yogi and a
Musselman.

content:
Christian child killed
to furnish blood for Jewish rite.

(Hugh of Lincoln.) (Cf. †V254.7.) **V. Manzini La superstizione
omicida e i sacrifici umani, con particolare riguardo alle accuse contro gli
Ebrei (2d ed., Padua, 1930); **Berger Mélusine VIII 169ff.; *Ward II 656 No. 3;
*Brown PMLA XXI 486ff. -- English: Child III 240ff., IV 497a.

child:
Captive released because of ability to recite beginning of
Genesis.

content:
(Cf. †C51.1.) *Encyc. Rel. Ethics Index 546a; Irish myth: *Cross;
Missouri French: Carrière; Jewish: Neuman.
child:
Cripples at shrine frightened and run away without
crutches.

Robbers promise to make offerings to the shrine of a hermit
if successful.

content:
*Frazer
Golden Bough XII 293 s.v. “Grove(s), sacred”; Irish myth: *Cross.

(Cf. †V135.) *Encyc. Rel. Ethics Index 18a; Irish myth: *Cross;
Jewish: *Neuman.

House of woman who launders clothes for church spared in
great fire.

child: Copy of gospels buried with saint.

Poverty-stricken couple wrap newly-born child in
altar-coverings.

content:
*Encyc.
Rel. Ethics Index 640c; Fb “kilde” II 119: Namn och Bygd XXXIII (1945) 1ff. --
Danish: Schmidt Danmarks Helligkilder (DF XXXIII); Irish myth: *Cross; England,
Wales, Ireland, U.S.: Baughman; Icelandic: *Boberg.
child: Oracles and auguries from holy well.

Fish in water from certain well: water refuses to boil till
fish are returned to well.

Ducks in pool in church: water in which they are placed
refuses to boil till ducks are restored to pool.
Hell as a monastery--the devil, abbot; sinners, monks.

content: Belief in miraculous powers of sacred relics.
child: Sacred relics carried in battle to aid victory.

The relics of saint protect horses from the attack of wild
beasts.

content:
Devout possessor of false relics miraculously receives
authentic ones.
child: Sham relics perform miracles if faith is great.

content:
Saint’s bones for lack of worship remove themselves from
church.
child:
Saint‘s bones miraculously removed from reliquary broken in
pillage.

Relics (images) carried away return to their original
church.

A cow licks the stone under which the secreted body of
saint is buried.

Testing the authenticity of relics: bones are cast into
fire; with great noise they jump away from the flames.

content: Possession of relic brings prosperity, its loss sickness.
Miraculous image of Christ impressed on napkin.

Image bars way of nun trying to escape convent to join
lover.
child:
Image of Jesus descends from cross and wounds nun leaving
convent.

content: Image blamed by suppliant for misfortunes.

Type 1479**, *Wesselski Arlotto I 196 No. 23; Spanish
Exempla: Keller; India: Thompson-Balys.
child:
God under compulsion: suppliant threatens to mutilate
(crush) holy image if his wish is not fulfilled.

content:
Preacher criticizes the likeness of Christ exhibited in his
church.

Says that it is unworthy of the
original. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
child:
Saint hangs cowl in thornbrake as symbol of Christ on the
Cross.

content:
Casting of image of Buddha delayed until a maniac‘s mite is
thrown into the furnace.

(Cf. †V1.11.) Hawaii:
Beckwith Myth 111; Cook Islands: ibid. 131; Marquesas: Handy 122; Tahiti: Henry
Ancient Tahiti (Honolulu, 1928) 344.
Motions of various kinds attributed to images.
child:
An apple is offered to a statue of the Virgin and her
child.

The infant reaches out and takes
the fruit. *Loomis White Magic 124.

content:
Encyc. Rel. Ethics Index 69a; Hdwb. d. Abergl. III 868ff.; E.
Lippert Glockenläuten als Rechtsbrauch (Freiburg im Breisgau, 1939); *P.
Sartori Das Buch von deutschen Glocken (Berlin, 1932).--Irish myth: *Cross;
Norwegian: Solheim Register 21.
child:
(Cf. †F993.) *Fb. “kirkeklokke” IV 260b; Wales, England: *Baughman; Finnish:
Aarne FFC XXXIII 47 No. 88; Finnish-Swedish: Wessman 72 Nos. 608--11; Estonian:
Aarne FFC XXV 135 No. 88.
Sunken bell travels on sea bottom.
Sunken church bell cannot be raised.
Church bell cannot be raised because silence is broken.
Church bell cannot be raised because person blasphemes.
Girl sold for new church bell.
Devil buys church bell and demoralizes congregation.

They have always come early before since they had no bell
to announce the time. Now they wait for the bell. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 92.

content:
*Encyc.
Rel. Ethics IV 61f.; Irish myth: *Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg.
child:
Holy water prevents a man from committing incest with his
daughter.
Holy water removes mark placed on man’s face by the devil.

content:
*Encyc. Rel. Ethics Index 629c; Gaster Thespis 270f.;
Jewish: *Neuman.
child:
Sight of holy fringe on garment restrains a man from
fornication and reforms the harlot.

content:
*Encyc. Rel.
Ethics Index 123c; Irish: *Cross, Beal XXI 335, O’Suilleabhain 112.
child:
Visit to certain church protects from drowning on
pilgrimage.
Stones for building church (chapel) miraculously supplied.
Place where a church must be built miraculously indicated.

Birds indicate the site where a church is to be built by
making a model of the structure on the spot.
Divine person points out site for church.

content: Priest is bribed into betraying the confessional.

child: *Encyc. Rel. Ethics Index 113b, 136c; West Indies: Flowers 580.
Monk seduces girl; then kills her; becomes infidel.

Nun hidden by abbess from pursuing knight betrays her own
hiding place to him.

Is afterwards
abandoned. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 13; Crane Vitry 159 No. 58.

Nun tempted into sinning with man who tells her God can’t
see things that happen in the dark.

content:
First-born son and one of every ten born thereafter given
to Church.
Priest uses cook-book instead of breviary.

child: Obedient and industrious nun the worthiest in the convent.

Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 690; Alphabet No. 322; Spanish
Exempla: Keller.
Truthful monk refuses to cheat even for his order.

Monk lives where people speak ill of him to avoid danger of
flattery.

Man captured by robbers is so confident that God will
protect him that he is saved. Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Cleric surrenders life that body may consecrate land.

content:
*Loomis
White Magic 111f.; *Encyc. Rel. Ethics Index 42b; Irish myth: *Cross; Spanish
Exempla: Keller; Jewish: *Neuman; India: *Thompson-Balys.
child: Kingship renounced to become an ascetic.
Since salvation is predestined, asceticism deemed useless.
Husband abandons wife to become ascetic.

Alphabet Nos. 709, 711, 712, 725; Swiss: Jegerlehner
Oberwallis 310 No. 32; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Alphabet Nos. 24, 145; Wesselski Mönchslatein 170 No. 135; Irish
myth: *Cross; India: *Thompson-Balys.

Ascetic faster increases his sufferings by placing food and
drink before himself.

Alphabet Nos. 22,
23; Scala Celi 4a No. 16; India: Thompson-Balys.
Saint refuses pearls as alms and asks for food.

Cleric
stands with hands extended in shape of cross. Irish myth: *Cross.

Saint always extends one hand toward heaven while
performing such acts as eating or reaping.
Ascetic cleric prays to become diseased.

Saint never wears woolen clothing, but skins of wolves and
other beasts.

Ascetic cleric sleeps (prays) with wet sheet (mantle) about
him.
Saint stands for seven years without sleep.
Ascetic cleric avoids listening to music.
Saint confines himself in narrow pen during Lent.

Saint stands (asleep) while bird builds nest and hatches
brood in his hand.
Ascetic cleric lives for seven years on whale’s back.
Ascetic cleric renounces world (to become a herder).

Monk refuses chance of having temptation removed since he
considers it strengthening to have it ever present to test him.

Evil ascetic misuses magic powers obtained through
religious meditation.
Boy takes twelve years to wash off ascetic‘s dirt.

content: Clerical vows because of disappointment in love.
child:
Man becomes hermit when he realizes selfishness of his
beloved‘s love.

content:
Former monk refuses to take pay for his work, considering
it as a religious act.

child: Monk who has left order punished (dies in torment).

Monk who has left his order forgiven and miraculously
reinstated.

Man who is disappointed with his religious order renounces
his vow.
Saint leaves his order because he is fond of music.
Anchorite tempted by money to return to worldly life.

content:
Irish: Plummer clxxxii, *Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg; Swiss: Jegerlehner
Oberwallis 301 No. 16; Spanish: Keller Espinosa Jr. No. 186; Jewish: *Neuman.
child: Mortals visited by angel in vision.
Angel announces birth of Christ to shepherds.

Angel bars abbot from his cell because abbot has cast out a
sinning monk.
Sacred books received from Buddha in person.
Precepts heard from Buddha in person.

Angels appear above grave of fallen girl through virtue of
prayers said by her lover (young monk).

content:
*DeVooys
Middelnederlandse Legenden en Exempelen (Den Haag, 1926) 129ff.; Spanish
Exempla: Keller; Jewish: *Neuman.
child: Christ born from crown of Virgin’s head.
Christ conceived on same day He was crucified.
Seventeen marvels at the birth of Christ.
Star shines through day of Nativity.
Shining cloud marks place of Nativity.
Vast intolerable light on night of Christ‘s Nativity.
Virgin suffers no birth pangs at Christ’s Nativity.
Elements silent and motionless at Nativity.

A “crown of thorns” among gifts given by the shepherds to
Joseph, husband of Virgin Mary.
Three (seven) druids come to adore infant Jesus.
Christ in form of an infant nursed by saint.
Christ in form of an infant fondled by nuns.

Christ as infant in mother‘s arms causes bare hillside to
become field of wheat as protection.
Fiery pillar as sign of Christ’s visit.
Jesus had “dark hair and a long red beard”.

Smith’s wife made nails for the Cross because her husband
believed Christ to be a true prophet.
Cross of Christ made of four kinds of wood.
Blood and wine issue from wound in side of crucified Savior.
Dialogue between Christ and the Virgin Mary.

Dialogue (debate) between Christ and Satan (at the
harrowing of hell).
The three bolts left on hell by Christ.

Irish myth: *Cross. Cf. North Carolina: Brown Collection I
642.
Christ sends message to voyaging clerics.

content:
Alphabet No. 482; *Loomis White Magic 72f.; Irish myth:
*Cross; Swiss: Jegerlehner Oberwallis 307 No. 25.
child:
Saint can perceive the thoughts of another man and reveal
hidden sins.

Truant boy learns long lesson while asleep with head in
saint‘s lap.

Saints blessed with ability to discourse in the native
idioms of the people whom they visit.
Saint understands language of wren, fly, cat.

content: Virgin Mary rescues man attacked by the devil.

*Crane Miraculis No. 23; Ward II 612 No. 30; Spanish
Exempla: Keller; West Indies: Flowers 580.
child:
Virgin Mary brings man a pact he signed with the devil and
frees the man from devil’s power.

content:
Virgin miraculously prevents nun (monk) from deserting
cloister.

Ward II 634 No. 34, 636 Nos. 7,
41, 667 No. 13, 721 No. 17; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
child: Image of Virgin tries in vain to keep nun from leaving convent.
Crane Vitry 160 No. 60; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Angels melt snow around saintly babe.
Service of angels marks saint’s destination.
Air above grave of converted druid full of angels.

content:
Ward II 603 No. 6, 606 No. 12, 610 No. 25, 618 No. 39, 648
No. 44; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Virgin Mary appears to erring man.
child:
Virgin Mary appears to erring monk and exalts him to
prayer.

His prayers weave her a garment.
Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Virgin Mary appears and pardons monk who has been too
overworked to pray to her.
Virgin Mary aids repentant slayer of priest.

Priest is resurrected in order to forgive murderer and
then is returned to tomb. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Virgin Mary appears to devout nun with infant Jesus.

The nun devoutly prayed to see Him. Spanish Exempla:
Keller.

content: *Chauvin VI 106 No. 270; *Loomis White Magic 53; Irish myth: *Cross.
child: Angels sing in honor of saint.
Angel choir responds when saint receives orders.
Angels sing on night of Christ‘s Nativity.

content:
Faithfulness to Virgin Mary, even if not to Christ,
rewarded.

child: Irish saint as “Mary of the Gael”.

content:
Virgin Mary prevents (retards) death so as to save sinner’s
soul.

Permits time for repentance and
absolution. (Sometimes resuscitation.) Alphabet No. 464; Ward II 606 No. 14,
633 No. 31, 650 No. 1; *Crane Miraculis Nos. 6, 7, 10, 31, 39; Wells 169 (De
Miraculo Beate Marie); Scala Celi 123a, 125b Nos. 674, 681. -- Spanish Exempla:
Keller.
child:
Virgin Mary brings man back to life after he has seen
hell‘s torments.
Miracles of healing performed before image of Virgin Mary.
Virgin Mary restores severed hand to Saint John Damascene.

He had cut it off to repress lust. Spanish Exempla:
Keller.

Virgin Mary saves life of man who at devil‘s instigation
has castrated himself.

She will not,
however, restore his severed members. Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Virgin Mary restores life to drowned man who always had
saluted her.

*Crane Miraculis No. 12; Ward II 605ff. Nos. 10, 18, 20;
Herbert III 26; *Crane Vitry 263 No. 296.

Virgin Mary supports robber on gallows because he once said
“Ave Maria”.
Ship in storm saved because of sailors‘ “Ave Maria”.

(Cf. †D2141.1.) *Crane
Miraculis No. 28; Ward II 626 No. 9, 640 Nos. 12, 14, 15, *677 No. 12.

Because of faithfulness in saying “Aves” the words are found imprinted on the
dead man’s
tongue. (Cf. †V86.2.) Ward II 612 No. 29, 677 No. 1, cf. 632 No. 30.

Blasphemer paralyzed in all members except tongue which had
once said “Ave Maria”.
Nun forgets to hail Mary and goes into the world to sin.

Joseph and Mary threaten to leave heaven when the man who
has always prayed to them is refused admittance.
Murdered boy still sings “Ave” after his death.

(Chaucer‘s Prioress’s Tale.) **Brown PMLA XXI 486ff.; Ward
II 656, 697 and passim; Herbert III 528; Wells Catalogue of Romances 166
(Vernon Miracles).

His head calls repeatedly, “Ave Maria”. Spanish Exempla:
Keller.

Virgin Mary will not let devil (authorities) take robber
noble who daily says “Ave”.

Virgin forbids devil to take robber as long as he continues
to say two “Aves” daily.

content:
Virgin Mary has dissolute monk buried in consecrated
ground: his only mass is that of the Virgin.

*Crane Miraculis Nos. 3, 9; Ward II 607 No. 15, 660 No. 29; Scala Celi 116a,
116b Nos. 644, 645; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
child:
Devotee of Virgin not buried in consecrated ground has lily
issue from mouth so that his grave is made known.
Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Virgin gives private mass to devout lady unable to attend.

content: Miraculous replacement of objects (animals) for saint.
child: Objects used as firewood for saint miraculously replaced.
Food (animals) eaten by saint miraculously replaced.

Loomis White Magic 70; Irish myth: *Cross; India:
Thompson-Balys.
Animals stolen from saint miraculously replaced.

Performing fox accidentally killed miraculously replaced
for saint.

Supply of lime for building church miraculously renewed for
saint.

content: Spanish: Keller, Espinosa Jr. No. 188; Jewish: *Neuman.
child:
English: Wells 76 (Joseph of Aramathie); Italian Novella:
Rotunda.
Angels appear and help boy prince slay treacherous uncle.
Angel shows saint where to dig for water.
Angel reveals location of lost (buried) object.
Angel brings cross as gift to saint.
Angel helps Peter to escape from prison.

content: Devotee of Virgin Mary given present by her.
Stella Maris: Virgin Mary as protectress of sailors.

Canney Revue de l’Histoire des Religions CXV (1937) 90ff.;
Krappe Review of Religion (1948) 376ff.

During a flood the Virgin descends into the streets to save
her image from the flood waters.

child: Flame illuminates cradle of sacred person.
Third son of king possesses sacred power.
Angel scourges mortal for disobedience to God.

content:
Angel beseeches at unholy grave of redeemed sinner until
body is moved to sanctified ground.

child: Angel leaves letter (book) with instructions for saint.
Angel tells saint where to build his church.
Angel informs saint of coming of guests.
Angels shed light upon saint’s tomb.
Angels set heavenly veil upon head of pious woman.

Saint commands return from dead with supernatural
information.

Saintly babe repeatedly found with arms extended in form of
cross.
Saint will drink only milk of cow milked by faithful woman.

Saint as baby refuses to take mother’s breast on Wednesdays
and Fridays.

Baptism of a wonder child is accompanied by a variety of
phenomena.
Place of saint‘s martyrdom perpetually green.
Martyrs emit milk instead of blood from their wounds.

Flowers grow on graves from the mouths or hearts of holy
persons.

Saint’s body remains unspoiled in the earth for a long
time.
Miracle saves saint from unjust censure.

Saint causes gluttonous reptile to leap from saint’s body
into bishop‘s throat and then return as proof of bishop’s injustice.
Seven Irish saints who never died.

Saint lives for 300 (100?) years without eating food or
uttering evil.
Saint promises to return from heaven.
Ale poisoned by druid miraculously purified by saint.

Druid raised in air, cast down, and brains scattered on stone
by power of saint.
Druid by spells seeks to drive saint from island.

Saint drives away an army by bringing upon it a dense and
smoky cloud.

(Cf. †D2163.4.) *Loomis White Magic 123; Irish myth: Cross;
India: Thompson-Balys.

Unusual fuel used by saints: burning stone, snow and
icicles, marble pillar, and green timber.
Broken objects restored to their original forms by saint.
Burned clothes restored to their previous form.
Holy man restores cut-off hands and feet.
Saint causes grey hair to grow in black.

Sinful beauty is converted and spends the end of her life
doing penance (Mary Magdalene, Mary of Egypt, and Thais).

Ground elevates itself to give protection or comfort to
saint.
Saint in anger shows strength: wall broken by his kick.

Saint disguised as poor man saves almsgiving king from
punishment in hell.
Lake of milk made through merit of saint.

Saint‘s blessing causes a river to be best place for
fishing.
Dispute between two saints settled by angel.
Objects mourn death of saint (holy man).
After birth of son holy person loses miraculous power.

House and family appear overnight to afford hospitality to
benighted priests.
Severed head of saint speaks so that searchers can find it.
Stone turns red when saint’s picture is removed.
Conversation of animals reveals to man how to become saint.

content: Holy place (object) glorified by angel‘s presence.
child: Train of angels rises from graveyard.
Angel passes daily over blessed stone.
God gives staff of Jesus to saint.

content: *Toldo II 99; Irish myth: Cross; Icelandic: Boberg.
Saints in several places at once.
Miracles performed under protection of Virgin Mary.
child:
Boy under protection of Virgin Mary pulled from well alive
after a week.
Virgin Mary saves devotee from death in waves.
Virgin Mary destroys Moorish army besieging Constantinople.
Virgin Mary saves devotee‘s son from shipwreck.
Image of Virgin Mary works miracles.
Hebrew the language of the angels.

content:
Alphabet Nos. 345, 354, 602, 637, 762; Irish: Beal XXI
305, 326, 335, O‘Suilleabhain 70f., 115; Spanish: Keller, Espinosa Jr. Nos. 45,
182; India: Thompson-Balys.
child: Birth of saint predicted by visions of miracles.
Pillar of fire rises over woman pregnant with future saint.
Saint identified by pillar of fire above her head.

Dazzling heavenly light by day and night marks place of
saint‘s birth.
Angels appear above place where saint is born.

Alphabet No. 473; Plummer cxxxviii, clxxviii; Loomis White
Magic 27f.; Irish myth: *Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg.
Supernaturally bright light marks sleeping infant saint.
Heaven falls upon infant saint. Irish myth: Cross.
Radiance fills church when saint dies.
Hand of saint made bright by Lord’s touch.

Too splendid for man‘s sight thereafter. Irish myth:
*Cross.
Column of light descends from heaven upon chosen man.
Lights show where the body of saint is buried.
Brake in which saint loses tooth bursts into flame.
House of saint filled with fragrance.
Aromatic smell of a saint’s body.
Oil bursts from ground as saint is made bishop.
Bell sounds at approach of saint.

Irish myth: Cross; England: Baughman; India:
Thompson-Balys.

Church bells ring without aid of human hands at death of
holy person.
Dead holy man stretches hand from tomb to honor saint.
Holy man passes through fire for his faith.
Only his clothing burns. Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Earthquake accompanies entrance of holy man into palace of
heathen emperor.

Saint falling into an abyss found perched in the branches
of a tree which projected from the cliff.
As soon as the man is drawn up, the tree vanishes. *Loomis White Magic 127.
Flowers fall from saint‘s mouth while he speaks.
Holy man restores a garden to bloom.

Sun sends shaft of heat to cook meat given persecuted
saint.
Roses lose thorns when saint walks on them.

Saint changes maggots in the sores of a nun into precious
stones.

Robbers who enter saint’s garden to steal are caused to
spade it up for him.

This proves him to be
saint. Spanish Exempla: Keller.

content:
Encyc. Rel. Ethics Index 246a; Irish myth: *Cross; India:
Thompson-Balys; Icelandic: *Boberg.
child: Oil flowing from relics has curative powers.

The wine (water) occasionally used to bathe relics assumes
healing powers.
Shrine of saint carried around to suppress pestilence.
Crippled saint miraculously receives horse and chariot.
Miraculous healing power of saint as child.
Leper cured by the kiss of a saint.
Saint’s blessing sufficient to control a mad dog.
Saint purifies monk with sign of the cross.

Woman relieved of incurable malady by kissing letter from
saint.
Wounds cured by saint leave no scars.
Cut off parts of body attached again by saint.
Men with enormous and unnatural appetite cured by saint.

content: Portrait of the Virgin appears to devotee.

Virgin Mary supplies mead for unprepared hostess of the
king.
Virgin Mary designates favorite for election for office.
child:
Virgin restores office to an ignorant man because of his
faith.
Virgin pardons man who repented for cheating in election.
Saint drinks poison without being injured.

content:

child: Angel of death spares mother who is suckling children.

content: Spanish Exempla: Keller; Icelandic: Boberg; Jewish: *Neuman.
child:
Angel appears to woman to warn her not to force girl into
marriage.
Angel in the form of an old man.

content: Devotee of Virgin is comforted in the hour of death.
Angel bars the way to Baalam‘s ass.

Alphabet No. 381;
Wesselski Mönchslatein 78 No. 68; *Crane Miraculis No. 34; Icelandic: Boberg.
child: Virgin Mary returns borrowed money and reveals cheat.

A man borrows money from a Jew with the Virgin as
security. Unable to return the money in time, he commits the money to the sea
with a prayer to the Virgin. The Jew receives it but claims that the money is
not paid. The Virgin reveals the cheat. Ward II 638 No. 10; *Crane Miraculis
No. 33; Wells 167 (Vernon Miracles).
Virgin Mary saves criminal from fire at stake.

content:

child: Man saved from lechery through prayer.
Continuous prayer sustains man through frightful vigil.

Scala Celi 151b No. 833; Irish myth: *Cross; Spanish
Exempla: Keller; Jewish: *Neuman.
Mariners saved from maelstrom through prayer.
Prayer at saint’s flagstone averts trouble.

Irish myth: *Cross; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Hawaii:
Beckwith Myth 105, 345.
Prayer for protection on journey to land of dead.

Prayers of devout woman free husband from death and
imprisonment.
Prayer of sinner changes his color from black into white.

The clever brothers work, the foolish brother only prays;
finally he acquires all the property.

Reciting martyrology will prevent decomposition of body of
one who recites it.

Prayer said by saint into his right hand restores displaced
eye of opponent.
Flesh of Artemis eaten as quail or bear.

Great sinner sent from one confessor to another. All say that his sins are too
great for forgiveness. Finally he succeeds. *Type 756C; **Andrejev FFC LIV
28ff.; Irish: O‘Suilleabhain 46, 48, Beal XXI 317.

Monks shrive selves clean under threat of complete exposure
of their sins by brother possessed of fiend.
Miracle attests fact that man does not need to confess.

He hangs his sack on a sunbeam. Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 146
No. 1805A.

Unnecessary for husband to confess as his wife has already
done it for him.
Penitent brings manuscript of sins to confession.

List of sins: schedule is returned miraculously cleansed of
all his sins.
Balance sins and cancel wrongs. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Performs very severe
penance, but cannot bear to humble himself and to stoop before the altar. (Cf.
†G303.16.9.) Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 818*.

content: Various ways of disposing of dead.
child:
Encyc. Rel. Ethics Index 79c, 545b; Fb “skib” III 243b; Icelandic: *Boberg. Cf.
Beowulf.

Thompson-Balys.

Hero buried in armor, standing with face toward land of
enemies.
Person buried in standing position with friends about him.

Man buried upright beneath kitchen stairway in order that
he may watch his family.
Head buried one place, body another.
King buried in his war car.
Lion buried in stone cave with gold letters.
Only usurers to carry body of usurer to grave.

content: Bones of dismembered person assembled and buried.

Money tied on corpse thrown overboard from ship in order to
secure burial.
child:
Shipwrecked each get a piece of the chief’s gold ring in
order to have gold with them in death.

Priest having nothing good to say about man
damns him with faint praise or gives anecdotes with unfavorable implications.
(Cf. †K1961.1.2.1.) *Wesselski Arlotto I 216ff. No. 64.

King buried with immense treasure in the ground of an
artificially dried river

; later the normal
course of the river is restored. *Krappe “Les funérailles d’Alaric”
Annuaire de l‘institut de philologie et d’histoire orientales et slaves VII
229--40.

maiden becomes a handsome boy on being baptized. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

child: Sign of cross protects from injury.
Sign of cross prevents child from being stolen from cradle.
Sign of cross prevents garment from burning.

Man dies because he has killed a man with the sign of the
cross on his forehead.
Martyr with sign of cross on his heart.

III 77, 416, 467, 487, 530; Scala Celi 69b No. 388; Alphabet No. 563.
Punishment for profane use of the cross.

Drunkard kisses cross, thinking it is a bottle of wine.

Miraculous manifestations to scoffers of the cross.

Alphabet. No. 230; English: Wells 97 (Chevalere Assigne),
89 (The Sege of Melayne).
Praying with arms extended so as to form a cross.

Loaf bursts in oven because sign of cross has not been made
over it.
The seven significances of the sign of the cross.

content: *Encyc. Rel. Ethics Index 193b; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Jewish: *Neuman.

Priest shows power of excommunication over host.

It turns black. Scala Celi 85b No. 495; Herbert III 446
No. 17.
Pirate excommunicated, goes on pilgrimage as penance.
Confession of sins of a pilgrim calms a great storm at sea.

Man returns from dead to protest against priest who has
been too easy with him at confession.
Confession without giving up sin punished.

Keller.
A man without a confessor is a body without a head.

content:

child:
Sincere confession miraculously obliterated as sign of
forgiveness.

Confession of monk who intended to rob monastery brings
forgiveness.

Eventually elected prior.
Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Prior pardons sinning friar who has confessed.
Sinner confesses before sinning and thus is pardoned.

Sinner’s tearmarks on written confession cause bishop to
pardon his sins.

content: Condemnation because of death without confession.

content: Pebble put in box each time mass is heard.
Faithful attendance at mass outweighs evil deeds.

Mass said for dead; they arise and say “Amen”.

Imprisoned miner kept alive by masses performed by his
wife.

Hearing masses causes triumph in tournament.

Angel takes absent knight’s place. He is delayed by going
to mass. *Liebrecht 29; Alphabet No. 462; Scala Celi 130b No. 714; *Ward II
662; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Man worships a cake which from time to time he eats.
Virgin Mary reproves a monk who sleeps at altar.

Negligent priests buried under bags filled with words
omitted from service.

Devils cause monk to perspire and stay away from church
service.

A son doubts whether the words spoken by the priests to
whom his father has willed a sum of money is worth so much. The words are put
on paper and are found to outweigh the money. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 465; Irish:
O’Suilleabhain 65, 113, Beal XXI 325, 335.
Host taken away from sinful priest.
Altar casts away host with louse baked in it.
Taking bath in a sacred river (Ganges).

Dying hero wants to be buried in the clothes of his brother
who killed him.
Dead not to be buried naked.

Man considering self unworthy to receive host given it by
God himself.
Wicked woman unable to endure presence of host at mass.
Sacrament effective even from unworthy priest.

Man who has refused such a sacrament shown a vision of a
leper giving men good water without harm. Alphabet No. 687; Irish:
O‘Suilleabhain 126, Beal XXI 334, 337.
Vision of sacrament in form of young child.

Alphabet No. 694; Scala Celi 66a Nos. 360--64; Toldo IV
49ff.; Irish: O’Suilleabhain 109.

Woman who has vowed not
to use make-up or ornaments thus rewarded. (Cf. †V35.1.2.) Italian Novella:
Rotunda.
Host given as pledge to keep one‘s word.
Voice from grave asks that it be opened.

Corpse spits out host because he has missed confession.
Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Sick men die and go to hell because they hesitate to take
sacrament.
Woman who eats before communion cannot swallow the wafer.
Christ in the desert overcomes devil by fasting.

Saint causes two youths to be fed with the best food, says
one is doomed to go to hell, the other will practice austerity in his old age.
Fasting to secure a prosperous journey.

Fasting on “Golden Fridays” as charm against certain
misfortunes.
Saint remains silent during Lent by holding stone in mouth.

Holy man eats pork and beef in Lent because pig is raised
on milk, ox on grass; but refuses to eat cake because it contains weevils (live
meat).

child: Jewish automaton will not work on Saturday.
Manna does not descend on Sabbath.

Various events, from creation to Resurrection, that
occurred on Sabbath.
Feast of Saint John the Baptist.

content:
Accidental calling on god’s name held to outweigh a life of
wickedness.

child: Skill in theft granted as answer to prayer.

content:
A tumbler, turned monk, dances while others chant psalms. He is praising God in
the only way he knows. *Herbert III 417; *Wicksteed Romania II 315; Romanische
Forschungen XI 223.

child: All dead are buried after battle.
Hero buried as unknown merchant in foreign country.

content: Study of Tora as religious service.
Power to which sacrifice is made.

Human sacrifice in connection with funeral.

make sacrifice.
God dislikes offerings beyond one’s ability.

content: Sacrifice made when treasure is found.

child: Skulls as sacrifice to a god.
Sacrifice of animals at the edification of a temple.

poured out to the gods. Greek: Homer passim; Chinese: Graham.

content: Sacrifice: olive branch laid on altar of Mercy.

child: Sacrifice to deity in order to obtain favors.
Sacrifice for a good year, crops.
Sacrifice to get help in danger.
Sacrifice to get snow and good conditions for skiing.
Sacrifice to find out where abducted daughter is.
Sacrifice in order that king may live 300 years.
Sacrifice to deity for return of abducted persons.
Rising smoke as sign of acceptance of sacrifice.

content:
Host miraculously given when it is refused a man by the
priest.

Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 129;
Alphabet Nos. 160, 420; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Icelandic: Boberg.

child:
(Cf. †D113.1.1, †E492, †G243.) Köhler-Bolte
I 134; Gascon: Bladé Contes pop. de Gascogne II 360 No. 4.

Angel holds mass in church on the day that the king absents
himself for sake of hunting trip.

Man who does not know how to pray so holy that he walks on
water.

Worldly-minded learn to pray by thinking of their usual
business.

Pauli (ed. Bolte) Nos. 334, 338;
Scala Celi 37b No. 209.
Woman shows that the Lord’s Prayer is the best.

Woman taught that it is better to pray before Christ‘s
image than before a saint’s.
“Beatus” best prayer for saving condemned souls.

Jews bribe woman to steal host for them: miraculous
manifestations.

Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 556; Mensa Philosophica No. 59;
Scala Celi 64a Nos. 349f.
Sacred image miraculously appears on stolen sacrament.
Stolen sacred hosts put into coffin.

Before death, a woman
asks to put a bag into coffin. It is filled with hosts. (Cf. †C55, †D1031.1.1.)
Lithuanian: Balys Legends Nos. 628ff.

Princess sick because toad has swallowed her consecrated
wafer.

Man who has received sacrament overcomes enemy, a
blasphemer.

Clothes of knight who kneels in mud before host as it
passes miraculously kept clean.

content: Man worships devil‘s image in order to secure advancement.
Ceremony of the proclamation of a Buddha.
Incredulity as to sacredness of host punished.
child:
Incredulity as to sacredness of host confounded by
miraculous appearance.

Incredulity of true transformation of host banished by
actual appearance of Jesus‘s body and blood.

Calves kept separate from cows in commemoration of hero‘s
death.
Drinking festival in memory of the dead.
Wedding and funeral festival on same time.

Virgil Aeneid XI 37; Greek: Aeschylus Libation-Pourers 423; India:

content: Shipman refuses alms: ship turned to stone.

Uncharitable knight drives bargain even in giving alms:
devoured by serpents.

His alms of corn
turn to serpents. *Herbert III 334 No. 7, 340.
Miraculous manifestations during act of charity.
child:
Bread stolen by St. Nicholas for purpose of feeding poor is
miraculously restored.

The more bread (flour) the monks give to the poor the more
God places in their bins.

content:
Saint shares punishment of sinful man whose cloak he shared
in life.

Children envious of money given by deceased father to
bishop.

In vision they take their father’s
body up and find a quittance saying that he has received more than a
hundredfold reward. Alphabet No. 302; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

child:
Man convicted of cheating at his bookkeeping is excused
when it is learned that he has given the money to the poor.
Charity rewarded above prayer or hearing of masses.

Irish: O’Suilleabhain 131; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 87 No.
756E*.

Queen gives away a sleeve of her dress: miraculously
restored.

Saint exchanges coat with beggar: gold sleeves miraculously
appear.

Man who has given all in charity has foot amputated:
restored miraculously.
Stones turn to gold for charitable money-lender.

Hence money borrowed for wedding is never refused by
lenders. India: Thompson-Balys.
Treasure given away by saint miraculously restored.

Man earns as much as he gave away for charity in his former
life.
Food given away by saint miraculously restored.
Charitable king blows nose after having given to beggar.

Huge ruby appears in his kerchief. Spanish Exempla:
Keller.

Jesus appears to St. Martin when he gives his cloak to
beggar.
Charity miraculously repaid: flame settles on forehead.

content: Merit for charity lost by asking work in return.
Son’s acts of charity save his father‘s soul.
Mendicant refuses to accept alms from barren woman.
Saint repeatedly bestows father‘s goods upon the poor.
Conqueror restores kingship to king for charity.

Pious man charitable to man who has formerly refused him
charity.

Alphabet Nos. 260, 754, 786, 789, 792; Irish: Beal XXI
337; Spanish: Espinosa Jr. No. 213.
Sinner reformed after visit to heaven and hell.
The only king ever saved in spite of himself.

Worship of particular deity brings reward of birth in
Brahma-world.
Man hears voice telling him to leave danger spot in mine.

Sinner who thinks of God saved; devotee who thinks of
worldly things goes to hell.

Man is prevented from taking passage on ship which later
sinks.

child: Pilgrimage to follow roads Christ walked.

**Becker Medieval Visions of Heaven and Hell (Baltimore, 1899); **Ward II
396ff. passim; Alphabet No. 622, 743; Dickson 265; Scala Celi 66a, 138b Nos.
362, 777. -- Irish: *Cross, O’Suilleabhain 57, Beal XXI 322; English: Malory
Morte D‘Arthur XV 3; Finnish-Swedish: Wessman 105 No. 932; Spanish Exempla:
Keller; Jewish: *Neuman.
Vision of angels defending road to heaven against devils.

*Becker (see †V511.1); Alphabet No. 610; Dickson 265; Herbert III
25; **Ward II 386ff.; *Crane Vitry 260f. No. 289; Scala Celi 34b, 74a, 85b Nos.
195, 422, 497. -- Irish myth: *Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg; Spanish Exempla:
Keller.
Girl sees vision of her mother in hell.

She chooses to live the poor life of her father which leads
to heaven. Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Visions of Land of the Saints.
God speaks in vision to devotee.
Only man without sin can see God.
Vision of the earth in the devil‘s snares.
Saint sees earth in snares. Spanish Exempla: Keller.

content: Man sees his own soul being judged.
child:
A clerk sees his good and evil deeds being weighed. He
asks them to throw his faith in Christ (the Virgin) into the scale. He is
saved. Ward II 651 No. 5; *Herbert III 471.

Man whose only good deed was unintentional sees this deed
outweigh all his evil in the scales of judgment.

Chairs of gold, silver,
crystal (glass) assigned to saints according to merit. (Cf. †A661.0.3.) Irish
myth: *Cross.

Wife sees moon enter mouth of husband; husband sees star
enter mouth of wife: famous child (saint) will be born.

Saint sees vision of flames covering Ireland quenched
except for sparks; then great light appears, dispelling darkness.

Flames are those of the faith brought by St. Patrick; they
become less until restored by St. Columkill. Irish myth: Cross.

When shower falls, small stone becomes larger, large stone
wastes away.

Vision of present and future
state of Irish church. Irish myth: Cross.

Vision in which swineherd sees yew tree upon a rock, with
an oratory in front of it and angels ascending from it.

Vision interpreted by druid as symbolizing founding of
Cashel and the royal line of Munster. Irish myth: *Cross.

Vision in which chieftain sees pair of gray seals that
sucked at his two breasts.

They are two of
his allies who are being overpowered by invaders. Irish myth: Cross.

Vision in which king sees whelp reared by him gather dogs
of Ireland and Britain against him but suffer death in battle at last.

The whelp is one of king‘s two foster sons. Irish myth:
Cross.

Vision in which saint foresees allegorically the
ramifications of king’s family Irish myth: Cross.

Vision in which king sees his four sons changed into lion,
greyhound, beagle, cur, which fight with alternating success, until lion
subdues the other three.
